questions.title: What is Picture Composition?
questions.question: What is a Picture Composition and what are its parts?
paragraphs: WHAT IS PICTURE COMPOSITION? A picture composition is a way to describe a given picture or to make a story out of it. Sometimes, it is also used to express and elaborate the thoughts and feelings suggested by the given picture.
TYPES OF PICTURES: The picture can be: • A photograph • An action scene • A quote written over a picture • A scene or a sketch • A famous personality
THREE PARTS OF A PICTURE COMPOSITION: 1. Introduction - Describe the setting (place and time) 2. Body - Explain what is happening (main action) 3. Conclusion - Give a message, feeling, or ending

questions.title: Step 1: Observe the Picture
questions.question: What should you observe when looking at a picture?
paragraphs: STEP 1: OBSERVE THE PICTURE Look carefully and note:
• Place - Where is the scene? (Example: park, market, beach, school, village)
• People - Who are there? (Example: children, families, vendors, farmers)
• Action - What are they doing? (Example: playing, shopping, walking, working)
• Mood - What is the atmosphere? (Example: Happy, busy, calm, exciting, peaceful)

questions.title: Step 2: Plan in 3 Parts
questions.question: How should you plan your picture composition?
paragraphs: STEP 2: PLAN IN 3 PARTS Your composition should have:
1. INTRODUCTION (Paragraph 1) • Describe the place and time • Set the scene for the reader • Example: "The picture shows a beautiful park on a sunny afternoon."
2. BODY (Paragraph 2) • Explain what the people are doing • Describe the main action in detail • Example: "Some children are playing football while others are flying kites."
3. CONCLUSION (Paragraph 3) • Add a feeling, message, or lesson • End with your thoughts about the scene • Example: "The scene looks peaceful and joyful. It shows how people relax and enjoy nature."

questions.title: Step 3: Use Good Language
questions.question: What kind of language should you use in a picture composition?
paragraphs: STEP 3: USE GOOD LANGUAGE Use the following types of words to make your composition interesting:
DESCRIBING WORDS (Adjectives): • crowded, colourful, peaceful, beautiful • sunny, rainy, busy, quiet, cheerful • tall, green, bright, golden, misty
ACTION WORDS (Verbs): • running, selling, playing, walking • chatting, laughing, working, resting • flying, swimming, dancing, singing
FIGURATIVE LANGUAGE: • "The park was buzzing with life." • "The sun painted the sky in shades of orange." • "The market was a sea of colours." • "Laughter echoed through the air."

questions.title: Sample Picture Composition: A Day at the Park
questions.question: Show a sample picture composition about a park.
paragraphs: SAMPLE PICTURE COMPOSITION Title: A Day at the Park

INTRODUCTION: The picture shows a beautiful park on a sunny afternoon. Tall trees surround the green lawn, and colourful flowers bloom along the pathways. Families and children have come to enjoy the pleasant weather.

BODY: Some children are playing football while others are flying kites. A group of people is sitting on benches and chatting happily. Near the pond, a man is feeding the ducks, and the sound of laughter fills the air.
CONCLUSION: The scene looks peaceful and joyful. It shows how people relax and enjoy nature after a busy day.

questions.title: Quick Checklist
questions.question: What is the quick checklist for writing a picture composition?
paragraphs: QUICK CHECKLIST FOR PICTURE COMPOSITION
Before Writing: • Did I observe the picture carefully? • Did I note the place, people, action, and mood? • Did I plan my three paragraphs?
While Writing: • Does my introduction describe the setting? • Does my body explain the main action? • Does my conclusion have a message or feeling?
After Writing: • Did I use describing words and action words? • Did I use simple figurative language? • Did I check my spelling and grammar? • Is my composition at least 100-150 words?
